The Planck Institute for Chemical Physics in Germany and the University of Heidelberg announced on Tuesday that they have established a new partnership to collaborate on research and sowing efforts. The partnership, which is supported by the Faculty of Agriculture of the Heidelberg University, is in the process of entering a critical phase. The Heidelberg-based institution will begin producing seeds from hybrid holly that will be genetically identical to the species, but one has the appearance of a plant and will be cultivated as a greenhouse in a bioreactor.The institute will also begin sowing seeds from the newly created Japanese yamato, which was named after the university and is due to be deployed in July. The plant is a hybrid of Japanese and European wild yams. The University of Heidelberg will donate 140,000 seeds for the project to the Heidelberg-based foundation.The partnership between the institute and the Heidelberg University was announced in a joint statement by the institute and the Heidelberg city council. American artist Lillian Gish, whose obsession with human scale fused to form a more abstract, post-Renaissance conception of the natural, died on December 13 at age eighty-five. Born in New York in 1939, Gish studied at the University of Pennsylvania, the University of Chicago, and the New School, then attended the University of Chicago, then to the University of Chicago, then to Princeton University, then to Columbia University, and then to the University of Wisconsin.
